textRun.content: Use the table of contents feature in Google Docs (appearing on the left unless hidden), this will make your life way easier with how this document is setup. I do not know how you manage without it.

To display an image use the “Show” command. This command appears on its own line and is followed by a “tag” followed by any number of “attributes”, followed by the location on the screen the character should be displayed. The tag uniquely identifies the kind of image (such as ford, stan, bg). Each attribute is a characteristic of the image and is found in the file name (space separated). Attributes can be listed in any order. Finally, the location on the screen is either left, center, or right (if we want more fine tuned positioning, let me know) and appears at the end of the command.
: File names for images follow this convention, but exclude the location at the end.

: If an image is shown with the same tag as an existing image on the screen, the older image is replaced by the newer. This is useful for background’s since they have, by convention, the tag “bg”, so by showing a background you are replacing the old one.
Neutral expressions are now assumed if an expression attribute is not included.
Show a smiling image of Stan in a speedo at the left third of the screen
“stan speedo smile.png” or “stan smile speed.png” (both will work)
Show the night club background image, replacing whatever current background image is
To clear all images from the screen and then display an image (likely always a background image), use the “Scene” command.
Clear the screen and display the “night club” background image
Show the night club background image and stan in a tuxedo
To make a character say something you do the following:
Name should match the tag used in their image file names (case is ignored for convenience).

To save keystrokes, you can both update the image and display the dialog text at the same time. In other words, if you want to change the expression or other image attributes of an already displayed image, you can insert them after their tag (“Stan” above) and before the colon. For example, if you want to both have Stan say “whee!” and change the image to smiling (until you change it back), you would write
If you want them to have temporary name put it in parenthesis like this: Stan (A voice): blah blah
To gather input from the player and store it in a variable (in this example “name”), you would do the following:
The text within the quote is what is displayed in the text input dialog.
Timelines are series of commands (such as players saying things, images being shown, jumps to other timelines, etc.). There are two kinds, labeled and naked.
Labeled timelines are identified by beginning with a Heading 2 formatted text. They can then be jumped to with the jump command.
Unlabeled timelines are the commands that fall beneath a menu item.
Use the “jump” command to jump to a timeline, identifying it by its label
To add 2 approval points, do the following
To remove 1 approval point, do the following
Other text that might be clicked
Each menu item corresponds to a timeline, falling a level of indentation in from it.

Nothing but dark water as far as the eye can see. The sun beats down mercilessly as your dehydrated body sprawls across a waterlogged section of wooden planking. You’ve long since lost the ability to sit up and scan the horizon for rescue. You pull your hat down over your eyes, resigned to your fate.
Your small raft is jostled by waves suddenly, but you barely notice. There’s a loud roaring assaulting your ears after days and days of silence.
Whoa, there’s somebody on this thing! Sixer, reverse engines!
You don’t know if this is just another hallucination, but the smell of exhaust smoke wakes up something inside you and you do your best to raise your arm, giving a limp wave.
Moments later your limp body is yanked upright by a strong pair of arms. You pass out.

You flounder toward consciousness with vague memories of someone holding a cup to your lips as you drank cold, clean water, and then later on, some kind of rich, salty broth. You are covered in soft, clean blankets. When your eyes open, you find yourself alone. You can hear the lapping of waves, the low vibration of the motor, and the murmur of a conversation somewhere outside. You sit up slowly and hold still until your head stops spinning. There is a large cup of water in a cupholder within reach, and you gulp it greedily, water spilling on your bare chest.
Your voice is rough with lack of use and dehydration, but the murmuring stops and you can hear approaching footsteps.

The space is small enough that if you leaned far enough out of the bunk, you could touch the far wall. There are photos and drawings stuck to the wall showing various people and places, but predominantly featuring a smiling pair of youngsters; a boy and girl who are clearly siblings. Some dirty laundry is evident on the floor along with a pair of old-man slippers. A dog-eared copy of a romance novel sits in the corner of the bed.
You lay back down and close your eyes, hoping that when you open your eyes you see a kind old wizard who is ready to tell you where and when you are and what the heck is happening.

A cool blast of air hits you as two tall, identical men enter the tight space. Squinting at them, you note that despite their matching faces and anoraks, one of them is slightly broader and wearing a red woolen beanie, while the other has a defined cleft in his chin and is sporting a wind-whipped, bicolored mane. Both have identical expressions of concern on their square-jawed faces.
Beanie Guy chuckles to himself as Cleft Chin guy shines a small pen-light into your eyes and grasps your wrist for a moment, taking your pulse, before noting the empty cup by the bedside.
Ah, you finished all the water, excellent. You were abysmally dehydrated. I highly doubt you would’ve made it another day out there.
I thought I was going to die. I owe you my life. Thank you for…all this.
Hey, no problem. I’m just glad we got to you in time.
What’s the eye exam for, and did you
Both men blush and look a bit uncomfortable.
It was that or allow you to succumb to hypothermia.
Bust out in laughter, hurting your dry throat.
Oh for cripes sake, I can’t believe I’ve become a meme!
See, Sixer! EVERYBODY knows that joke!
Cleft Chin picks up a bundle from a nearby shelf and leans toward you.
Your clothes have been laundered and are currently drying. In the meantime you can borrow these.
He places a pile of what is clearly their spare clothes on the side of the bed before straightening and folding his arms behind his back.
Oh yeah, by the way, I’m Stan and this nerd is my brother Ford.
Welcome aboard the Stan-O-War 3! What’s yer name, and where’re ya from, anyway?
Pleasure to meet ya $name. So, how’d you end up in the middle of the Atlantic?
You were testing out a prototype watercraft.

I was testing out a prototype submersible watercraft when the craft’s Artificial Intelligence decided it wanted to explore the ocean on its own. It went rogue, ejecting me from the cockpit before diving out of sight.
Ha! I would expect as much! I’ve never met an artificial intelligence that had an ounce of loyalty. Still, that is fascinating work! I’m glad we happened along before you succumbed to the elements.
You tumbled off a cruise ship while drunk
Well, last I remember, I was in a drinking contest with a circus contortionist on a cruise ship.
Oof, those things are huge! That drop had to be a doozy. That ship is long gone by now. I hope you won, at least!
I was fishing when there was a strange noise and the sky went all red. The boat shook, and I felt weightless. That’s the last thing I remember before waking up in the middle of the ocean.
Fascinating! I wonder if you encountered a temporary wormhole, or if perhaps you were abducted by aliens! You’ll have to tell me everything! Once you’re quite recovered, naturally. *Smile
No way, poindexter! Once our new guest recovers, we’re doin’ some DEEP SEA fishin! I even brought the Joke Book! *Smile

You’ve only got the clothes on your back at the moment, and lacking any form of identity, air travel is out of the question. Even if you had enough in your bank account to pay for a trip home, you have nobody to call to wire you the money.
What am I going to do now?

Your head spins and you flop back down on the bunk. Beanie Guy reaches a hand out and feels the temperature of your forehead. Out of the corner of your eye you see him exchange some subtle body language with his twin, who speaks up.
You should get some more rest. We’ll wake you in a few hours for dinner, and then we can discuss our next move.
You’d thank them again if you had the energy, but you’re already drifting toward unconsciousness.
You wake up a few hours later, ravenous. You struggle weakly into the clothing that’s been left for you and then call out.
Ford responds to your calls, entering the small cabin with a warm smile. He puts an arm around your shoulders and escorts you to a small booth table adjacent to the galley
Stan saunters up and places a plate of hot food in front of you. You tear into it like a wolverine, barely able to register the conversation they’re having over your lowered head.
[Illustrations of table full of hotdogs, rehydrated mashed potatoes, pitt cola, and cans of brown meat]

Eventually, your shoveling slows and you slump against the table. Ford insists that you drink more water, and once you’ve done so, Stan lifts your glutted body with a solid arm, ushering you back to what you now realize must be his own bunk. You’ve gathered that the twins have been taking turns sleeping in Ford’s bunk. You smile up at Stan from under the blankets, meaning to thank him, but you drift off too quickly.

You’re awakened by a sudden jarring of the boat. You hear directions shouted from the deck down to what must be a dock as the Stan-O-War 3 maneuvers carefully into a berth. You feel the long, drawn out slide as the boat comes to rest against the dock. Moments later, Stan knocks lightly on the door of the cabin before entering.
Welcome to Reykjavik! That’s Iceland’s main port, if ya didn’t know.
Stan adopts a conspiratorial expression and leans closer to you.
Look, I know ya don’t have the paperwork to get on a plane from here, but if you wanna try to bluff your way through, I can probably find somebody that can help…
The exterior illumination is eclipsed as Ford’s tall frame fills the doorway.
No, Stanley! $Player is a resident of $Home and we will see $pronoun returned home WITHOUT putting $pronoun in danger of incarceration.
work with that. Unfortunately I don’t have any money. I’m pretty sure forgers want cash, and the airlines usually want paying as well.
Ok kid. We won’t leave you hangin’, no matter what. We’ll find a way to get you home.
I don’t want to be a burden. Are you sure?
Could you actually do that? If you could get me home, that’d be amazing!
Indubitably. We’re on a planet-wide search for anomalous activity. I’m sure there must be something to research that brings us near to your home.
Phew, you don’t know how relieved I am to hear you say that.
We’re happy to help, right Stanley?
What if I just.. Y’know, hang out with you guys until you end up somewhere I like? Hopefully somewhere with palm trees and frosty beverages? I can be helpful! Ehh?

I don’t know.. Are you sure this is what you want, kid? It can get pretty dangerous out on the ocean. Airline Security is nothin’ compared to the things we’ve seen. Plus, we could be caught out there for weeks. Months even. You’re signing up for a lot of salty clothes, crappy food, endless ocean, and Sixer monologuing about nerd stuff. All. The. Time.
Ford looks at you meaningfully after a sidelong glance at Stan

This is not a comfortable life, $player. We spend a lot of time in peril, or simply suffering monotony. Then again, I’d really like the chance to run some tests on you and research your predicament on the off chance that the cause was anomalous.
I, uhh… sure, ok. Yeah, that sounds fineI guess.
Stan neutral [Gives Ford a sidelong glance]:
What do you think, Sixer? It’d be nice to have someone else to talk to for a while.
Ford neutral [Gives Ford a sidelong glance]:
As long as they’re aware of the dangers, I’m for it.

The three of you wander through downtown Reykjavik, stocking up on supplies and gear. The guys generously purchase you an anorak and sundry other cold weather necessities as well as extra clothes and underthings, including a bathing suit. They also purchase a hammock to hang from the Stan-O-War 3’s beams to make you a bed. After delivering these things to the boat, you all stand on the dock and debate what to do with the rest of the day.

I’d love to visit the Whale Museum! I have long suspected that a narwhal horn specimen housed there is mislabeled. It’s possible that the horn isn’t genuine, and may actually be evidence of an entirely unknown species!
Haven’t we seen enough fish to last us a lifetime?
Dammit Sixer, that’s not the point!
Y’know, Mabel said something about music clubs with hot tubs around here, we should look for one o’ those!

There is also a local film festival scheduled for tonight. A documentary filmmaker I’m familiar with through her work on the topic of Icelandic cryptids is showcasing a new film. Regrettably, I believe it to be a departure from her previous work; tonight’s film seems to be a period drama set in turn of the century Iceland.
Tell ya what, if that’s what the kid wants to do, we’ll all go. If not, how ‘bout we split up and $Player can tag along with whoever $pronoun wants?
Join Stan for soaking and sipping on the town.
Hot tubs, booze and tunes? You’re singing my song, Stan!
Yeah! Let’s go get our swimsuits on and fancy ourselves up. We’re paintin’ the town whatever color you want tonight!
Just be careful, Stanley, and message me if anything happens. I’ll meet you two back here later tonight.
Sure thing Ma. Have fun with the fish!
Join Ford for an educating journey and a mystery to solve.

I love museums! Speaking of museums, the Phallic Museum is right down the street! I wonder if it’s open. We should go there afterward; I bet they have an anomalous wang on display, we just have to find it!
Um, yes…indeed. I’ll just grab my bag and we’ll be off.
Uh oh, he’s bringin’ his Science Bag. You’re in for it now.
I’m outta here! Meet you guys back here tonight ok bye!
Jump A Night at the Museum
Take them both to the Theater.
I don’t think we should split the party. Who knows what evils lurk in the cold streets of Reykjavik? Let’s go watch the movie and critique it later according to our own criteria!
We can even make it a drinking game if we go get a fifth of whiskey.
Yeah! Every time someone broods on a windy clifftop, that’s a sip.

Every time the servants defy the leader of the household and help one of the noble daughters who’s fallen in love with someone they don’t deem appropriate steal away to be with her lover, that’s a sip!
Wow, you’ve really given this some thought.
Wait, did you just make a DD&MD reference, $player?
Mmmaybe… Anyway, we’ve got a destination, let's GOOOOOO!

You’re delighted to discover that Iceland’s Whale Museum is only a couple of blocks away from the dock. As the two of you make the short trek, Ford expounds excitedly regarding the difference between the common Narwhal and the remains that are on display. The cryptid, which Ford has dubbed the “False Narwhal”, has only been seen a few times. Not much is known about it. He believes the animal was caught by untrained hands many years ago, and the horn was mistaken for the horn of the much more common whale.
Huh, bummer. I was hoping for something more mysterious and paranormal.
Unfortunately, science is often quite banal. However, without the boring parts of science, the inexplicable phenomena wouldn’t hold as much import, wouldn’t you agree?
Looking a bit deflated, Ford smiles and nods, striding ahead with purpose.
Oh, absolutely! Without the rigors of the scientific process, how can we tell the difference between the
Exactly! We can’t even begin to speculate on the unknown until we’ve made absolutely sure that it
unknown using the technology currently at our disposal.
of frauds and number-fudgers! Don’t they ostracize anybody who wants to research anything deemed ‘paranormal’? Why bother with mainstream science? It’s all baloney!

Yes, well. It’d be nice to work in a vacuum, not having to rely on the oversight of others, but science wouldn’t get anywhere without the convergence of many minds producing copious amounts of data. Even if some of it has been falsified, that which isn’t is invaluable to science’s ultimate goal.

Inside the museum, you are greeted by life sized whale sculptures, perfect down to the barnacles and lice that generally adorn the behemoth’s  tough, slippery skin. Ford is a volcano of information that continues to erupt as you wander through the exhibits. You consider telling him that you know most of this already, but he seems so delighted to impart this knowledge that you can’t bring yourself to stop him. His enthusiasm is contagious.

While most of the exhibits are sculpture replicas, the “Narwhal Horn” is solidly actual, sitting behind a velvet rope. It’s an impressive three meters long and looks, to you, like the horn of a unicorn that undoubtedly suffered from chronic neck pain. Ford is studying its root closely with a triumphant expression.
Yes, just as I suspected!This horn is not ivory at all, and moreover, it’s a
helical spiral, meaning it isn’t a Narwhal horn!
What the heck are you talking about? It looks like a Narwhal horn to me.
But, you see, the helical form is…  never mind.
Whoa, no way! It’s helically reversed! We need to take a sample of this, like now.
I’m so ready, tell me what to do!
How are we going to take samples if we can’t touch it? Did you contact the museum? I’m sure they’d let you run some tests.
I did, but the answer is tied up in so much red tape that I’ve decided to take matters into my own hands.
I’m going to head to the bathroom on the left. I will wait there while you use this item by rubbing it against the artifact repeatedly until a viable sample is collected.
It was the most effective item I could find for this purpose. Are you in or not??
Of course! I’ll head into the bathroom when I’m done.

The long spiral horn is held in an alcove behind an informative plaque about the majestic Narwhal. You do your best to be inconspicuous as you lean over the large plaque and stretch your arm out to scrape the horn with the implement that Ford provided. It’s not easy. Only a sprinkling of material comes off. You persist as long as you think is prudent before sweeping the tiny pile of shaved horn into your gloved hand and making a break for the bathroom.

You duck into the bathroom to find that Ford has set his ‘Science Bag’ on the counter and spread several unidentifiable mechanisms around it. He holds out a petri dish and you dump the horn shavings into it.
This should only take a few minutes. You can feel free to enjoy the museum while I run the tests, if you like.
Sure thing, I’ll wander back here in a few minutes.
Ford nods distractedly as you turn and exit the bathroom. You meander around the museum, learning more about whales than you ever wanted to know.

Having exhausted your attention span, you wander back toward the Narwhal horn exhibit and the nearby bathroom. You notice a couple of people hunched over the horn itself, speaking animatedly. One of them is in a uniform.
You shimmy over to the bathroom door and crack it open.
We’ve been made, Ford. Time to boogie!
They called Security! We gotta go!

Ford stows all of his instruments into his bag without hesitation and you’re spun around as he hooks his arm with yours and exits the bathroom at speed. He marches you quickly to the exit as shouts ring out behind you.
Why are we doing this in the bathroom? Shouldn’t we do this on the boat?
Well, we could, but I have these instruments at the ready now, so why not?
But what if someone notices what we did!
Well then, we shall deal with that when and if it occurs.

You stand idly by as Ford tests the particles of horn in several unidentifiable mechanisms. Harrumphing to himself, frowning and grinning at different intervals, and finally shouting “AHA!” with triumph, Ford completes his tests.
You hear raised voices from the museum and peek out of the bathroom to see a couple of uniforms and an attendant clustered around the horn exhibit.
Ford, we gotta go. We’re busted.

Ford stows all of his instruments into his bag without hesitation and you’re spun around as he hooks his arm with yours and exits the bathroom at speed. He marches you quickly to the exit as shouts ring out behind you.
I’m curious to see what you’re testing the sample for, if that’s ok.
Certainly! Here, add the contents of this vial to the sample while I calibrate the instruments.

Ford fiddles with the various apparatus as you pour a small vial of clear liquid into the petri dish. Finally, he pulls on some six fingered rubber gloves before reclaiming the sample. As he feeds it to the various devices, he dictates his actions to you in a low, even voice. You are fascinated. Some of it is beyond your grasp, but most of it is familiar enough for you to understand that this sample didn’t come from a Narwhal, but instead from an animal with properties that are not wholly understood by current science. You are only pulled out of your nearly trance-like attention by the sound of raised voices in the hallway.
Oh no, I think we’re in trouble. Ford, we gotta go!

Ford stows all of his instruments into his bag without hesitation and you’re spun around as he hooks his arm with yours and exits the bathroom at speed. He marches you quickly to the exit as shouts ring out behind you.

The moment you exit the museum, Ford has clamped his arm around yours and is sprinting back the way you came. Your feet barely touch the ground as you hear shouts ring out behind you. A corner is turned, and then another, and finally Ford slows enough for you to find your footing and jog alongside him toward the dock and the Stan-o-War III.
How does he not seem winded at all?)
Well done! I’ve still got some further tests to run, but tonight was a total success!
Sweet! I’m happy to help. I wonder how late Stan will be out.
We can expect him anywhere between now and never. If dawn comes and he’s not back, we’ll go get him.
Shouldn’t we go now? What if he’s too drunk to find his way home or something?
As you finish speaking, you hear a scrabble of footfalls on the icy pier and recognize Stan’s silhouette as he reaches the Stan-o-War III.
Ask and ye shall receive, eh?
Anybody followin’ me down the pier?
Not that I can see. I think you’ve pulled it off, whatever ‘IT’ was.
Great, now where’s my orthopedic back pillow?

Stan dances out of the Stan-o-War 3 in a white and burgundy three piece suit. He wraps his anorak around him and pulls on his beanie before exchanging some cautionary words with Ford as they part ways. Dressed as best you can in your own clothes, wearing your bathing suit underneath, you once again thank your lucky stars that of all the mariners that could’ve scooped you out of certain death in the middle of the ocean, it was these two generous, likeable dudes.
Aaah, crap. It just occurred to me; they’re going to want ID at the door, aren’t they?
Don’t worry about a thing, kid. Once we’re there, follow my lead. No questions.

Throbbing bass can be heard before you round the corner of the street leading to the club. You’re pretty sure you can feel it in the soles of your snow boots. A brightly colored sign declares ‘Monkey Bar’, lighting up the surrounding slush and grit with dazzling neon rainbows.
You’re surprised when Stan sticks to the shadows on the far side of the street and bypasses the club, ducking down a dark alley beside it, with you on his heels.

Stan sniffs the air and stops at a chained opening in a tall fence. He peers through a crack for a moment before pulling something out of his pocket. You see a flash of metal in his hand as he manipulates the padlock, which opens easily. Next thing you know, he’s pulling you through the fence and closing it behind you.

You find yourself in a shadowy nook behind the club. It boasts a couple of garbage bins, and a bucket filled with sand sits by a propped open fire door. Stan pats his pockets and brings out a cigar case, popping it open to reveal a half-smoked stogie that he pops into his mouth. You’re still marveling at the speed with which he popped that padlock when the door to the club opens and a man in nothing but a speedo comes out holding a cigarette and lighter. Stan turns to him.
The man graciously steps up to light Stan’s cigar, cupping the flame with his other hand. You notice a smeared stamp on the back of his hand that looks like a cartoon monkey face.

Puffing on his cigar, Stan steps back and thanks the man with a “þökk fyrir”. The two of you move to huddle on the other side of the enclosure. Stan pats his pockets again and pulls out a handful of disparate writing utensils. He selects one and stows the r
Stan flicks his eyes toward the smoker. Once the man finishes his cigarette and reenters the bar, Stan relaxes

You reach out and he grabs your hand, uncapping the writing utensil, a blue ballpoint pen, with his mouth. He begins to draw on your hand, occasionally using his thumb to smudge the lines. When he releases it, you take a look at his work. It looks identical to the blue monkey stamp you saw on the hand of the other patron. He gets busy drawing on his own hand.
Stanley, you are the coolest person I have ever met.
Heh, I have my moments. You did great too, kiddo!
Exactly! You didn’t balk, you didn’t sweat, you didn’t backpedal. You’re a natural. Now to get some free drinks.
Are you sure this is a good idea? What if they don’t buy it?
Trust me, kiddo. This is kids’ stuff. You should try breaking out of a government facility while floating around in zero gravity.
Don’t worry about it. Now to get some free drinks.
No wonder you’ve been to jail multiple times.
Hey, everything’s legal if there’re no cops around.

Stan leads the way into the club. Nobody stops you as you weave between bare, sweaty bodies toward a wall of cubbies. Stan shucks his clothes down to a pair of tropical patterned swim trunks. You follow suit, stowing your clothes in the cubby beside Stan’s before following him into the heart of the club. Stan takes a look at one of the crowded hot tubs and winces.
Ehh, on second thought, sitting in what’s essentially old man soup doesn’t have the same appeal as I imagined it would. Wanna do the sauna room instead?
Yeah, that water is probably full of arthritis ointment. I’m with you.

You find a free bench in the crushing, oppressive heat, sweat beginning to roll down your body. Stan disappears for a few moments and reappears with two cans of beer which immediately bead up with condensation.
Here ya go, kiddo. I hope ya like weird foreign beer.
The two of you pop your beers open and Stan gestures for a toast.
Let the party begin! Whadda we toast to?
To Stan Pines, hardened criminal and unparalleled seaman!
To the Stan-o-War 3 and its heroic captains! Without you guys, I’d be fish food.
Yeah, to the Stan-o-War 3! It took a lifetime to get her, but it was worth the struggle.
To free drinks, sloppy security and public nudity!

Many of the patrons are nude. They tote around small towels to place on the benches before they sit and chat away just as they would in a cafe. While the clientele are varied, the vast majority of them are men, on the older side. It’s becoming difficult to find a place to aim your eyes, so you focus on Stan. At first you’re grateful that Stan seems content to remain in his swim trunks, but the more you consider the idea, the more you find your eyes roaming over his solid, sweating and obscenely hairy body.

Your eyes travel back up to Stan’s and find them scanning the room. But…did you see him dart his eyes away from yours just a second after you looked? He upends his beer and shakes the last drop into his mouth. You do the same, and he swipes your empty can and disappears for less than a minute before coming back with two cold ones.

So… $Player. If you’re gonna bunk with us for a while, you should know some things. Sixer…uh, Ford and I have been through some stuff. We both have a bit of a hair trigger. What I mean is… probably you shouldn’t sneak up on us or like, wake us up by shaking us or something. We tend to, uh… lash out pretty hard. You don’t have to walk on eggshells or anything, just try not to spook us, ok?
Yeah, I understand. Thanks for telling me.
The two of you sip your beers and sweep your gaze over a panorama of wrinkly ballsacks for a few more minutes before Stan speaks again.
Whoever the DJ is should be drawn and quartered, or possibly tarred and feathered. One of those old-timey deaths, to match the intensity of the one my eardrums are going through right now.

As you’re about to respond with a similar opinion, another wrinkly ballsack turns to face you and Stan. You look up to see a scrawny chest and a helmet shaped like a lizard head. A muffled voice emerges from within.
Oh eh, heheh, we were just joking around. Bara grín!
Your accent is atrocious, and who the hell are you? This is the album release party! We’re supposed to have this place to ourselves. I’m calling security.
Before Lizard Head had even gotten three strides away, Stan grasped your wrist and dragged you through the throng toward the cubbyholes.
I’m trying! Pulling on pants is so hard when you’re wet!

There are raised voices back in the center of the club as you pull on your boots. Stan practically drags you out the front door. There are a couple of taxis parked outside, and he leans into one of their windows. You can’t catch what was said inside, but as Stan ushers you to a nearby alley and as you both back into the shadows you hear the taxi burn rubber, leaving the area at high speed just as the club doors open. Lizard Head is there with a few others. All are speaking Icelandic rapidly, but you sense defeat in their tones as the taxi speeds out of sight. Stan lets out a relieved sigh.
Well, I guess that’s enough fun for one night. Sorry about all the law breaking and the running and the…you know what I mean.

Are you serious? This has been one of the best nights of my life! Stan, I know I’m standing here shivering because my wet bathing suit is soaking into my clothes, but I wouldn’t change a moment of it!
I knew you were a kindred spirit, ya little hellion! Now, let’s get back to the boat and get into some dry clothes. I’m freezing my balls off!
This is HEAVY, Stan! What if I get taken to ICE JAIL! I don’t want to get turned into a snowman!
Relax, kid, they’re off our trail now. We just need to get back to the Stan-o-War 3 without freezing our asses off.
Yes please. Put me back in the boat!
Good, they’re distracted. We’ve got to get back to the boat. It’s down that road, right?
You said it. I feel like a drunk raisin. Wait a minute, shouldn’t we wait up for Ford?
That won’t be necessary. I was able to retrieve a sample and run some tests, and you won’t believe what I’ve discovered!
Save it for tomorrow, nerd. The kid and I are tuckered out.
Quit it with the ‘kid’ Stan, i’m not that much younger than you!

After an extended period of waiting for Stan to be satisfied with his ensemble for the night, the three of you finally embark on the voyage to the theater. Looking at his Omniwatch, Ford steers you past the theater, leading you on what turns out to be a much longer route to a liquor store. On the way you pass by the world’s only Phallological Museum, and you make a few humorous remarks that have Stan guffawing and Ford blushing madly.

A sea of anoraks mill around you and Ford as you shuffle toward a row with three free seats. You push Ford in first, not wanting to be caught on the edge of the banter. The lights dim, and finally you hear Stan grumbling his way past knees to get to you, laden with a cornucopia of snacks and popcorn.

From one side comes a tide of pedantry regarding the movie’s props and scenery. From the other, a volley of grumbles and shouts aimed at the characters on the screen. You munch on popcorn and sweets. Eventually a bottle is passed around and the twins begin marking out shot-triggering tropes and sip-worthy scenes.

Finally, with a roar of indignance from Stan, the final act plays. There is a smattering of applause from the room until a thank-you to the director is announced over the intercom, disclosing her attendance.

The audience roars to life with more applause, but not before Ford and Stan spring out of their seats intent on speaking to the woman herself. You grab their sleeves to prevent yourself from being lost in the crowd.

Did you see the markings on the rocks in the first scene with the protagonist? The same symbols appear, all nearly obscured by darkness, throughout the piece. It must be a cipher, but I can’t crack it without more information!
There is NO WAY it’s supposed to end like that. They musta had some kind of issue that made it impossible to shoot the right ending. Maybe the actors got sick or somethin’. I need to know!

You cling desperately to the guys as they barge their way to the front of the mob. The crowd seems tame until Stan and Ford barrel through on their mission. Someone takes umbrage with the twin’s rough urgency and has words with Stan. Before you know it, a brawl has broken out. You duck behind a row of seats and wait until you can see both Stan and Ford.

Leaping over the seats, you grab both Stan and Ford by the collars and make it clear that the time to exit is nigh. They seem to come out of their violent reverie and both nod. Ducking through the now agitated mass of puffy arctic clothing, you all find your way to the exit just in time to hear sirens. With a wild look shared between you, the three of you bolt down the street in the shadows, ducking through alleys and skidding around icy corners until you finally make it back to the Stan-o-War III.

The three of you toss quick stories back and forth as you prepare for bed. Stan clears some space in the storage room and Ford helps you hang your hammock from the rafters, taking some time to also enlighten you on the correct way to use a hammock.
After wrapping yourself in your blankets and laying crosswise in the hammock, you fall asleep quickly, smiling to yourself.
